is equal to the maximum number of coins.
And if it does, we're going to trigger

of here, once we have added our one,
because we've collected the coin, we're
just going to check to see if that value
is equal to our maximum number of coins.
And if it is, set the game to paused.
Let's take a look at exactly how this is
done. So with this, what we're going to

And using a node called a branch node.
And again we can just drag out from this
return value.
We can then return true and do one set

But then what we're going to do is we're

What this is going to do is just simply

With that done, if we go ahead and
compile now
and minimize this and press play, you

that I wanted to mention just while
we're doing this, it's just a really
handy keyboard shortcut is when we're
duplicating these, if we hold down alt
and then click and drag on one of the

little bit easier to navigate. What I
can also do is I can hold down shift alt
and then click and drag on this and it's
going to not only duplicate that coin,
but it's also going to move our camera.
Just to recap on the code to make sure
that we are understanding the logic for
all of this. What's happening is when
our bp_platforming
character overlaps, it's triggering this
code sequence. And what it's doing is
taking the collected coins variable in
our bp_platforming
character and increasing it by one and
then setting it which is kind of like
saving it. We print that to the string
just for testing purposes. But then at
the same time we are running a branch
statement which just checks to see if
the collected number of coins now is
equal to our maximum number of coins. If
it is, we're pausing the game and
collecting that last coin. If it's not,
we're just destroying the coin and just
letting them carry on as normal. So,
that's some really straightforward logic
there. And this is possibly going to be
some of the most difficult code that
